reviewText: Pat Paulsen was, apart from Alfred E. Neuman, one of the great comic Presidential candidates, and a very funny guy in an understated, dead pan brand of comedy. This is not the greatest TV skit show of all time, but it has aged well and you get to see "Super Dave Osborne" before he became famous for that role.
summary: Pat Paulsen for President any body?

reviewText: This is an offbeat and very funny show; Pat was a guest comic on a number of other shows too.
Title: N/A

reviewText: I always enjoyed Pat Paulsen on the Smo Bro's - he was a pro at deadpan mistiming. Unfortunately he was not allowed to present fully developed material on his own 1970 ABC show.When watching the shows I couldn't believe they were so barely professional - this was network television, after all, not a local affiliate production. When I watched the extras his son Monty revealed why. The entire half season run (13 episodes) was taped in two days. There was no time for much of anything - sets, revisions, even retakes of flubbed lines.Steve Martin was a principal writer. His mark, and the beginnings of his comedy evolution, are obvious, but I'm guessing he might have given up half of his salary to have had more time to work his ideas and the nascent material. In all honesty, and apart from nostalgia, most of the material is not all that funny, certainly not in a "whole greater than the sum of the parts" sort of way.The shows become even more rickety when the extras are watched. These extras, which highlight some of Pat's best pieces from other venues, suggest what his Half a Comedy Hour might have been. The extras are the highlight of the set and alone are worth the (discounted, anyway) purchase.Just remove the word Hour from the title and you'll have a good idea what to expect.
Title: N/A

reviewText: This was an interesting era in television. Pat was a major hit on the TV series The Smothers Brothers, especially with his run for president. Pick fun at the establishment in a way never done before. Unfortunately it all hit home far too well and the series was cancelled. It is great to relive some of the unusual humor Pat and his writers created to attack the days and times of my youth and a government being forced to account for its actions like never before.

summary: Still funny after all these years

reviewText: I am excited to see this again. I have very fond memories of this funny show, including Pat Paulson's interview with Daffy Duck. Sometimes old TV is best remembered rather than seen again, but I think this might be the exception. I hope so. I may not be fourteen any more, but I am not that much more sophisticated than I was then. Sad, huh?

reviewText: The Pat Paulsen Half A Comedy Hour was a mid-season replacement in 1970 that my brother and myself never missed. I remember it as one of the funniest shows on televison and am eager to see how it stands the test of time. Regular routines included a takeoff on a popular series of the same period called "Then Came Bronson" about a disillusioned man who quits his job to travel the country on his motorcycle and "find America." Called "Then Came Paulsen" it included tongue-in-cheek titles like "I've Got A Monkey On My Back And I Can't Stop." Another frequent segment was called "Hobbie Hut" where Paulsen regularly destroyed the projects of his American Indian co-host. Interview segments included Daffy Duck and a very funny double interview with a very ratty looking Smoke the Bear and the Cookie Bear form the Andy Williams Show. I'm very excited about the opportunity to see this again. Paulsen was a gifted comedian whose career was too short.
Title: N/A
